data.text: A Bicycle Navigation / Route Planner with Offline Maps and GPS
Is there a gps or map app that works off line? Thanks

You can download offline maps for google maps. But maybe give MapOut a try. It offers route planing by painiting a line on to the map. It's based on OpenStreetMap. https://mapout.app
MapOut ‚Äì iPhone/iPad app: Offline map for hiking, biking or as city map
mapout.app
data.author: Heni Amundsen

data.text: Mapout is a great app.
data.author: Martin Schoenherr

data.text: MapOut is a fantastic bicycling tool for ride planning. It is really quick to use and simple to edit. Contour lines as well; it has detailed contour maps. Only available for iOs - iPhone and iPad.
data.author: Il Padrone

data.text: Trailforks

data.text: I use premium komoot and it works offline but I need to save the maps when im online ... touring spain atm with no mobile coverage i rely on wifi only ... i map with wifi and save offline

data.text: Mapfactor Navigator, on Android. Excellent. And free - as for now. Has both.

data.text: 2nd that

data.text: I agree. Easy to create routes while offline. You can download kml files from online (eg. from RideWithGPS) that will appear as a line on Maps.me.

data.text: I use OsmAnd for walking and biking. You can download 7 area's for free, but we pay 10 ‚Ç¨/Year do download all the maps we want. This is much cheaper then Komoot.

data.text: A paper map.
data.author: Andrew John Ganner

data.text: here we go ... you download the maps of the country online, and then you can use it off line.
data.author: Miguel Brichant

data.text: I can recommend Mapy.cz (don't worry, it's in English), you install the App, then you can download off-line maps for the particular areas that you need - so for example, here in Poland the country is covered by 16 separate maps, but if you're only visiting, say, the northwest then you only need to download the map(s) that cover that part of the country, hence saving space on your phone.
data.author: Roger Orysiak-Marrison

data.text: For those who say paper maps, have you used a GPS? Both are good and if possible you should carry both. Personally I use a Garmin, have ride with GPS and maps.me and carry a paper map
data.author: Tanya Bosch

data.text: I carry paper maps, use Kamoot and Google for backup particularly for big towns or if I'm temporarily misplaced. I am still old school and prefer the paper. :-)
data.author: Sue Chapple

data.text: Maps me
data.author: Ian Harris

data.text: Memory map works offline

data.text: Download Google/Petal Maps of the areas you want to travel. The GPS functionality still works

data.text: Maps.me works this way.
data.author: Grant Jacobs

data.text:
We use Oruxmaps which uses Open Street Maps and you can download Maps for anywhere in the world. The Maps are free and Oruxmaps is only about 5 euro. It's a really excellent programme with every feature you could possibly want. https://www.oruxmaps.com/cs/en/
Home
oruxmaps.com
data.author: Bernard Wragge-Morley

data.text: Paper maps, fantastic battery life, never charged one in 40+ years.
data.author: Keith Warner

data.text: Maps. Me
data.author: Scott Cunningham

data.text: Guru maps. All you need is a smart phone.
data.author: Tony Tinsley

data.text: Mapy.cz app (english version) - free offline maps worldwide. Download the region You need. Great search functions (water, shops, accommodation etc), great offline navigation. Tracking available, gpx import and export. Easy and intuitive to use. Nice map layout. Great zoom slider.
data.author: Supp Suppinger

data.text: Maps.me has always been what I‚Äôve used in multiple countries over the last 5 years
